com.gdxgame.core

Class GameState

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gdxgame.core.GameState
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Screen

    public abstract class GameState
extends Object
implements Screen
    GameState is one of the core classes besides GameStateLogic to handle game states. Each game consists of multiple gamestates (f.e. show main menu, game, show highscore, game over, ...). Each GameState has its own resources (f.e. audio or graphic files that are important for that state) and its own GameStateLogic instance. The GameStateLogic instance is used to handle the real logic of the gamestate while the GameState instance is used to handle the resource management.

    It extends the libgdx Screen class so that the GDXGame class can use it for the Game.setScreen(Screen) method. The class also forwards the important Screen methods (=show,hide,render,resize,pause,resume and dispose) to its GameStateLogic instance.

    A GameState is configured (=which gamestate uses which logic) within the GameStateType enum.

      GameState(GameStateType type, GameStateLogic logic)

    • Constructor Detail

      • GameState

        public GameState(GameStateType type,
                 GameStateLogic logic)

    • Method Detail

      • show

        public void show()
        automatically called whenever the Game.setScreen(Screen) method is called and the gamestate gets active. This normally happens within the GDXGame.setGameState(GameStateType, boolean, boolean, Object) method. It is used to load the resources of the gamestate by calling its loadResources() method and to make a call to the logic's GameStateLogic.initialize() or GameStateLogic.resume() method.
        Specified by:
        show in interface Screen

      • hide

        public void hide()
        automatically called whenever the Game.setScreen(Screen) method is called and the gamestate gets inactive. This normally happens within the GDXGame.setGameState(GameStateType, boolean, boolean, Object) method. It can be followed up by a call to dispose() if the gamestate is no longer needed and gets removed. The call is forwarded to the logic's GameStateLogic.pause() method.
        Specified by:
        hide in interface Screen

      • update

        public void update(float deltaTime)
        automatically called whenever the GDXGame.render() method is called and the gamestate is active. Updates the gamestate by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.update(float) method.
        Parameters:
        deltaTime - time passed since last frame

      • render

        public void render(SpriteBatch spriteBatch)
        automatically called whenever the GDXGame.render() method is called and the gamestate is active. Renders the gamestate by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.render(SpriteBatch) method.
        Parameters:
        spriteBatch - reference to the GDXGame SpriteBatch to draw things

      • render

        public void render(float delta)
        This method is not used anymore since we split up the render call into our own update and render method within the GDXGame class.
        Do not use this method
        Specified by:
        render in interface Screen

      • resize

        public void resize(int width,
                   int height)
        automatically called whenever the Game.resize(int, int) method is called and the gamestate is active. Handles the gamestate resize logic by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.resize(int, int) method.
        Specified by:
        resize in interface Screen

      • pause

        public void pause()
        This method is called only on android devices whenever the game loses focus. Pauses the gamestate by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.pause() method.
        Specified by:
        pause in interface Screen

      • resume

        public void resume()
        automatically called whenever the Game.setScreen(Screen) method is called and the gamestate gets active and was already initialized. This normally happens within the GDXGame.setGameState(GameStateType, boolean, boolean, Object) method. It is also called on android devices whenever the game gains focus again. Resumes the gamestate by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.resume() method.
        Specified by:
        resume in interface Screen

      • dispose

        public void dispose()
        automatically called whenever the Game.setScreen(Screen) method is called and the gamestate gets inactive and is no longer needed. This normally happens within the GDXGame.setGameState(GameStateType, boolean, boolean, Object) method. Disposes the gamestate's resources by forwarding the call to the GameStateLogic.dispose() method and to the disposeResources() method.
        Specified by:
        dispose in interface Screen
